text:
How can be possible that the precision matrix returns values larger than 1?
I found that with my own data but also running the nilearn example
http://nilearn.github.io/auto_examples/03_connectivity/plot_inverse_covariance_connectome.html#sphx-glr-auto-examples-03-connectivity-plot-inverse-covariance-connectome-py

I get 
In [111]: estimator.precision_.max()
Out[111]: 2.0537018448578808

In [112]: estimator.precision_.min()
Out[112]: -1.0522529001195888

I get this just using the above example with the estimator as in the example http://nilearn.github.io/_downloads/plot_inverse_covariance_connectome.py
estimator = GraphLassoCV()
estimator.fit(time_series)
title: estimator_precision_ larger than 1

text:
I think that these matrices should be diagonal-dominant -- which ensures that they are SDP -- which they are.
@grjd Maybe you're bothered by sign flipping of coefficients ?

* The off-diagonal coefficient of the precision *once normalized by the diagonal  of the precision* represent partial correlation (up to a sign flip).
* The diagonal of the precision represents partial variance. They have no reason to be equal. 
HTH
Please check the code  but I think it is P_{i, j} -> P_{i, j} / sqrt(P_{i, i} * P_{j,j})

yes SDP they are . I find confusing that the diagonal elements have very different values, if the variables are gaussian the precision represents the partial correlations, then, the diagonal elements should have all maximum precision.

So you normalize each off diagonal element in row i by the the diagonal element i?
P_{i, j} -> P_{i, j} / P_{i, i}

> How can be possible that the precision matrix returns values larger than 1?

Precisions are not normalized, unlike partial correlations. So yes, it's
not surprising.

> The precision matrix (also Ledoit) dont recover the main diagonal,

What do you meean?

> i should have maximum values for the diagonal, normalized or not.

And what do you mean here?
